A sculpture of a hollow vase created from the ground up with deposition printers in mind.  Version 2 has a taller and wider neck.

Made in Modo.  
The test print photo displays a print at the highest resolution and largest size possible on a Rep 2.  I think the larger the better for this print if you get it too small the ribs might become prone to warp and breaking.  
This is a hollow structure with no bottom - you could you use whatever surface you place it on as a base and it could easily become a container for long items like pencils or pens, etc.  It might even become a light shade if sized appropriately.

comments.text: Some parts of this are really hard to print well.  What layer height do you recommend?
comments.author: PHDerp

comments.text: I printed at the finest layer height because it has a curved surface.  However I think the key on a print like this is make it is as large as possible on your build plate, doing that will make those angled parts print more reliably.  It wasn't a problem on my Makerbot Rep 2 but I did make it fill the the build volume.
comments.author: PHDerp

remixed_from.author: cevinius
remixed_from.title: MobBob V2 - Smart Phone Controlled Robot

remixed_from.author: stevemedwin
remixed_from.title: Customizable Straight Beam for LEGO Technic

description.text:
This is an optional part you can add onto MobBob V2 to give him arms.
The "Socket" parts mount on either side to provide peg holes for MobBob's shoulders. Arms then plug into those pegs.
I'm planning to created some fully 3D printable arms, but I have not done that yet. (However, I've provided a template for the pegs to enable others to create their own arms if they wish!)
While I haven't provided printable arms, I've did upload a shoulder piece that features a Lego Technics-compatible beam. That piece enables you to make arms using Lego Technics pieces.
I've made 2 sample arms using Technics pieces. One is a static arm with a poseable claw. The other arm has a Sharp IR Distance sensor strapped on.
To support the Sharp IR Sensor (and other future sensors), I've added 2 connectors to the Bluno Beetle. These connectors provide 5V, Gnd, and an Analog pin. These connectors can be used with a wide variety of sensors, and should enable different sensors to be swapped in fairly easily.
With this new easy-to-swap arm system, I wanted to make it possible for MobBob to be fitted with a wide variety of sensors. This can enable MobBob to be used as a platform for learning about and experimenting with different sensors.
I haven't updated the software, but I will be updating the Arduino code to support the Sharp IR sensor, and also updating the Android app include new functionality that makes use of the sensor. I'll post a video once that's ready.

I still drilled a hole and glued a plastic peg to go inside the screw hole of the charger to prevent it from rotating.  I almost built this feature in, but that would have reduced other possible uses for the hook.

This is a pan flute based on the Spirit Flute from one of my all-time favourite Nintendo DS games, the Legend of Zelda: Spirit Tracks. You may notice that the colors on my print isn't the same as they are in-game, that's because i simply didn't have the right ones.
You may also notice that the paint looks a bit wierd.
I didnt have the right ones there either, so the gray is aluminium tape, and the yellow and purple is nail polish. It took me a good while to design, so i really hope y'all like it. And for the people wondering, yes it's Really loud! i tested it with a decibel-meter app.
And from about half a meter away it displays around 100db, now that's impressive for such a small flute! if you want to you can add some blue rope and the beads to the sides as shown in the last picture, i removed them because of the make it loud challenge's rules. and no. i can't play it.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

30%
Glue or weld the pieces together and paint it.

First of all i played the game a bit to get a good look at the flute.
Then i used an in-game screenshot to draw the outlines of the cog and to calculate the lenght and width of the pipes.
Then i just put it all together in 123d Design. the in-game screenshot i used. the original sketch.

After a couple of months the grip of my DJI Inspire case broke off. The plastic parts with which the rubber grip is screwed to the suitcase is done very cheap.
Options were buy a new suitcase or replace the part. I decided for the 2nd option. On the photo you see the black part which broke (and I glued together to measure), a green ABS print of the design and a print in Taulman's T-Gaze filament which I used for the final prints, because of it's strength. The parts are screwed with M2.5 Screws of 20 mm and 25 mm and a washer to the suitcase.
I recommend printing the part with the top side down.

The frame of my Prusa i3 Hephestos was a little shaky, so I wanted to find a way to reinforce it while changing as few parts as possible.
With only four printed parts, two 8mmx350mm steel or aluminum rods and some glue you can considerably improve your printing quality. instructions:
  • Print the files y-corner-left, y-corner-right, and two times holder-top
    The quality doesn't really matter
  • Saw an 8mm rod into two 350mm pieces
  • Replace the y-corner parts of your printer with the ones you just printed.
  • Stick the two rods into the holder-top and add a little glue
  • Stick the assembled rods with the holders onto the printers frame and into the corner parts. Add glue if necessary
    • Important: I designed this for a Prusa i3 Hephestos. So the distance between the corner part and the frame should be about 90mm for it to work. EDIT: Added step-files for customization

title: Hand Pumped Single Octave Pipe Organ

description.text:
This is a working pipe organ.
The 'wind' (airflow in organ language) is supplied by rocking the pump back and forth, the wind is then channeled to the pipes where the sound is created, the wind passes by a set of valves attached to keys as well as a perforated disc allowing for two modes of play.
When the keys are locked in the depressed position all channels are open and pipes will sound wherever there is a hole in the disc, the pattern of holes dictates the tune. However when the keys are unlocked and the disc replaced by the disc space filler all channels are closed unless a key is pressed allowing for playing of the organ.
Unfortunately I am yet to design any discs, if you are musically minded please feel free to make some, let me know and I'll add them to the thing files.
Please print, enjoy, and comment with feedback.

Every aspect of the pipe organ has gone through many iterations.
The pump was originally meant to be a set of bellows however I soon found this to be impractical as the required flexibility could not be achieved with PLA (I can make the files available if anyone would like to attempt printing in a flexible material).
Designing the air channels was originally straight forward as I only intended the organ to play the disc, then I had the idea to add a set of keys and it suddenly got a lot more complicated.
The keys took a lot of fine tuning to get them to spring back to the closed position.
The pipes proved particularly difficult to get right, after many failed attempts at designing my own (I thought it would be relatively simple) I did a bit of research and found it's quite an art, using the equations found at www.rwgiangiulio.com I was finally able to produce a working set.

You will need to print:
  • Wind Supply:
    • 1x Mouth Piece
      or
    • 1x Pump (either in 1 or 3 pieces)
    • 1x Pump Base
    • 4x Valve Part A
    • 2x Valve Part B
    • 1x Linker
  • 8x Key
  • 1x Key Base
  • 1x Organ Base
  • 1x Pipes
  • 1x Disc Turner
  • 1x Disc (tunes to come!)
  • 1x Disc space filler
    • Printing and Post-Printing Notes:

  • I have only printed this in PLA and that works just fine but please feel free to experiment and report back - for example, I can imagine that the pump may be more efficient if printed slightly over sized and in a flexible filament.

  • The objects are all orientated how I found it best to print, some parts (eg the pump) are best printed with supports even though it requires some patience to later get the support material out of the hard to reach areas.

  • The windsheets (small slit where air escapes from the pipes) have to be very thin for functionality, they are within the tolerance of most consumer 3D printers but may require cleaning out for proper function.

  • Some parts may require filing to fit comfortably - it's better to print too big than too small!
    • Assembly:

  • Insert 2 of the valve part A's into 2 of the valve part B's these fit into the pump base with the valve facing down (best fixed with superglue), insert the other 2 valve part A's into the pump, and slot the pump into the pump base.

  • Align the 8 keys with the key base and push a length of 1.75 mm filament through to secure.

  • The pump and pipe bases and the are joined with the linker, and the key base is slotted into the pipe base ensuring that all keys align with their respective holes.

  • Finally add the pipes and you're ready to go.

description.text:
As You can on the picture I have 2 very large filament spools, and experiments with spoolholder-"feets" with 4 ballbearings gave too much friction.
This model have holders for 2 different sizes of large filamentspools: 52mm inner diameter and 105mm inner diameter. - Do You have rolls with another diameter, You can create some holders and change them whenever You feel like it!
In the middle of the center spool You put a 22mm ball bearing - in each end. And the rod holding it all is a 6mm threaded rod. - The stand is a little thin for a 5kilo role, but its strong enough for printing!
The stl files contains one of each component, so You have to duplicate them in the slicer!

This is the code for a completely customizable omni-wheel in OpenSCAD.
It allows the user to choose wheel radius, subwheel size, how many subwheels are created, what axis is used for the wheel and the subwheels, how thick the frame or the connectors is ...
Basically any important value!!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: The resolution is freely choosable, however, smaller size is preferred for the main wheel piece while higher layer heights should be used for the subwheels. Use the setting "generate" to choose between the main frame (1), of which you have to create two pieces, and a subwheel (2), of which you should create however many you have set in the setting "num".

Assembling the subwheels! Once you have created all the required pieces (2 times the main frame for the wheel and however many subwheels you have specified) you should then continue assembling the omniwheel. This is a quite straightforward process:
Simply place the subwheels in the correct positions (which you can see in the OpenSCAD Preview when having "generate" set to 1) and push whatever you chose to use as axis through the connectors.
I have chosen 1.75mm filament as axis. It serves this very well, and is recommended for use as it is small, cheap, and allows smooth rotation.
If the connectors on the omniwheel break on the weak outside piece (which probably will be rather small), this is no need for concern!
Simply glue the filament to the connector and everything should stay in place. As you do this it is also recommended to use a bit of lubricant to allow smooth wheel movement, however this is optional. Assembling the main wheel! Once all subwheels are in place, simply take the two main pieces and push them together in a way that the teeth fit together.
With a bit of force the pieces should slide together and connect firmly. Additionally a bit of glue can be used to fix the pieces together.

description.text:
While working with cymon on the xiangqi pieces, the idea for a box came about...  The top is embossed with the Chinese "xiangqi".
(The box very barely fits on a ToM HBP... 116mm square.)
Thanks to cymon for making a more decorative box top!

(Use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10397 instead for something that can be printed easier.) When printing on a ToM HBP, you'll want to make sure the platform temperature is set to 110 (or higher), as the piece goes right to the edges. You'll also want to close up the windows of the ToM. If you don't do so, you'll likely get corner curling. (Even so, I still got a little corner curling.) For my bot, I set the print outline in skeinforge to 0.5mm, and immediately peeled it off before the bot started to extrude the actual piece. This lets the bot center itself just right, otherwise the endstops get in the way and cause x/y-axis drift. (The alternative is to calibrate your platform exactly right for an almost maximal print.) If you're not having luck with printing to the edges, scale down the pieces and tweak the openscad file. (The emboss was generated using my export plugin for Illustrator... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9529) Notes: as uploaded, the pieces are a little loose; you might be able subtract 1-1.5 mm from the interior dimensions. The lid doesn't sit quite well, so the top lip interior may need to be trimmed a little. (OR increase the interior height.) My hypothesis on the very-corner-curling involves the bolts holding the platform to the xy-axis. Since the bolts are metal-touching-metal, they're probably acting as heat sinks, thus cooling the corners of the HBP. Since the corners are cool, whatever is extruded there obviously is going to cool faster, and so curl.

title: Surface Pro 3 Desktop Docking Station Mod

description.text:
Turns your Surface Pro 3 in to a Desktop Computer by just sliding it in sideways. For this thing I disassembled the original SP3 Doking Station (which was kinda hard and probably voided the warranty, but pfff... who cares? its a dock...) and only kept the lower case, PCB and connectors. I hotglued a USB extention cable and a mini DP to HDMI adapter in the upper slots. I haven't been using the Docking Station for a while, so i decided to make an expermient. Microsoft claims "the Surface Pro 3, the tablet that can replace a laptop." It did! I don't have a Desktop anymore and use the SP3 as my main machine now. Then the question came up: "Can it replace a Desktop as well?" I didn't use the Docking Station because:
  • it uses lots of desk-space (when a monitor is added)
  • still creates a cable-salad ontop of you desk
  • I had problems with scaling between the SP3's own Display and the 27" 1080p Display
  • the Typecover sometimes gets caught in the mechanism
    • I use this Docking Station for about a month now and I need to say: It makes my Desk nice and tidy, is even easier do slide in than the original and works a treat with multiple monitors. It's probably the smallest and most portable desktop computer I ever had.
    The only problems i had so far were it's power limitations of a mobile CPU and GPU. I'm still working on a release button, an option to mount it horizontally (unterside of Desk) or vertically (side of drawers like in pic) and support for a regular charger, so you don't need to disassemble a dockingstation.

To successfully make this thing you need following things with your SP3 to work:
  • Surface Pro 3 Docking Station
  • Surface Pro 3 Type Cover
    • The Docking Station's Warranty will probably be void (depending on how nicely you remove the bottom sticker). Before diassembling the Docking Station, you need to connect it and set the external monitor as main monitor, since the SP3 will be closed and facing towards a wall.

• Tidier on your desk and uses less space
    (because I want to use my G510's G-Keys for quick OpenSCAD programming, without having an extra keyboard or having to remove it all the time)
  • easier to slide in
    (The Type Cover doesn't get caught in the mechanism and as simple as putting it in a bag or a drawer)
  • less problems with scaling
    (because Windows still didn't fix it properly)
  • Fan is less annoying since it's unter the desk
  • Turns your Surface even into a 3-way hybrid! Tablet, Laptop and Desktop! Awesome!
  • Easier to switch to a real desktop since the cables are at the right place

title: X ends with rod distance adjustment

description.text:
These X-ends allow to adjust the distance between the X rods and the Z bearings, and so to compensate the lack of accuracy of the plastic printed parts.
The clearance between linear bearings and rods can be precisely set for a smooth, quiet motion of the X-carriage with no sticky spots.
The fine adjustment is performed by a M3 screw. Turning clockwise increases the rod spacing by 0.25mm each turn. The X-carriage used with these X-ends is: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:798169

  • x-end-idler_v12.stl and x-end-motor_v12.stl: Z rod and lead screw in line along X axis
  • x-end-idler_v12s.stl and x-end-motor_v12s.stl: Z rod and lead screw shifted by 1 mm to take into account the shift of Z bearings after insertion

title: Variable WORD Sculpture
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: by Robert Halter
More Options and view only Colors

• Enter a Message in lowercase Letters [a-z] with one or more non printed '/' Character.
  • Example: "me/ss/age"
  • Use the '/' for new Lines. Only tilt last Letter in first Line.
  • Add only one '/' at the End to tilt the last Letter in a one Line Message.
  • Example: "sculpture/" use xTranslate = 45
  • Add only one '/' at the Begin to normal write the Message in one Line.
  • Example: "/sculpture" use xTranslate = 45
  • Minimum one Letter between two '/'.

• zScale - thickness of Letters [mm] - default 35 - [35,30,25,20,15,10,8,5,4,3,2,1]
    i.e. use 3 or 4 for Beverage coaster
  • xTranslate - horizontal movement of Letter [mm] - default 48 - [50,49,48,47,46,45,44,43,42,41,40,39,38,37,36,35,34]
  • zRotation - tilt angle of last Letter in first Line. [deg] - default -45 - [-20,-25,-30,-35,-40,-45]
  • view text in selected color - default is 'Red' - make a screenshot and add it to your Remix

Licensed: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike (by-nc-sa)
see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creative_Commons I liked the Work from isaac budmen with his four WORD lettered Sculpture,
and his ... give it new life through new eyes and new authors ...
and read the comment 'Any 5 words sculpture?' Then I decide to extend his Work (the OpenSCAD File) with ... to allow to print more Messages.

This has been the ultimate project for me, and is now finally functional after 8 months of blood, sweat and ABS. It is also made on my 3d printed makerbot ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3285 ) The printer can easily get taller by adding more z-elements and replacing z lead-screws and wobble arrester bars. I would then end up with almost 800mm build hight. It wouldn't surprise me if this is the largest printed multi-piece object, as it is built from 15+ lbs of ABS plastic. Specs Footprint: 800x560 Build envelope: 500x300x200+ Platform: Heated with 800W, custom ordered, silicone wire wound element. - Kapton sheet, custom ordered to fit platform (500x300) Motors: NEMA 23 Extruder: MakerBot StepstruderÂ® MK6 Plus Electronics: MakerBotÂ® Generation 4 Interface: PC/Mac or MakerBotÂ® Gen 4 Interface Board Kit v1.1 Motion: all axis uses linear bearings for smooth motion. Build duration: 8 months Plastic used: 15+ lbs Price: 3000$ (approx.) Video of the printer in action: http://hacknorway.com/wordpress/?p=82

I have uploaded one file containing all pieces, as i cant imagine someone else making this. If there is some element of this build you want me to post an stl off, just send me an email or use the commenting system:)

I think that many people want to know is that posiblle

comments.text:
Yes this works great!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:999486
I experimented with mounting in front and keeping both extruders, but I couldn't get everything to fit without it hitting the front of the printer on large prints, and it was also tough to get it to the right height. I based mine on an earlier design, but made some improvements. Using the Jtech photonics 2.8W laser, it cuts through just about anything. PROJECTOR LAMP
/ IED student project Designed by: Eduardo Rosales y Javier Benavides LAMPARA PROYECTOR
/ Proyecto estudiantil para el IED Diseñado por: Eduardo Rosales y Javier Benavides

Here is a functional printable assembly of the iconic MP40 sub-machine gun. As there are no technical drawings for the parts I have created it using a few reference dimensions and then scaled to suit. The assembly breaks down into parts that the real weapon is comprised off but each part has had to be modified to be printable and functional when assembled. Currently, I have only posted the full assembly version STL's as I want to print the assembly myself before I release the files so that I know that every assembly is going to be successful so nobody is put off printing it. My end goal is to correctly size springs for the recoil and trigger mechanisms so it can be cocked and fired (obviously minus real bullets). For more of my replica weapons, see my collection - https://www.thingiverse.com/lilykill/collections/replica-weapons Follow me on twitter @ https://twitter.com/lilykill1, and instagram @ https://instagram.com/lilykill1/ and facebook @ https://www.facebook.com/Lilykill-253119598353137/ where you can stay up-to-date on my current projects and releases. Update 05/01/16
STL's uploaded but I have not printed this myself so please leave feedback if you do.
The only part that I havent included are the stock as I havent finished the parts for printing yet.

A 3D printed PLA version of a wooden snail pull toy I made in shop class many years ago. After seeing a number of wonderfully designed wooden pull toys on the web (a few of which are also snail pull toys!) I was reminded of the flat, wooden, wobbly, poorly painted pull toys, including a snail pull toy, I built way back then. This 3D printed version is much better than what I was capable of making many years ago in wood, so I think I'll be "modernizing" a few more of my early woodworking pull toys. Video of prototype is here: https://youtu.be/xz5HDgi2r7g. All pieces are printed with the exception of the wide rubber bands used for traction and yarn used for pulling. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Study "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Print and assemble all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.
Place wide rubber bands around the circumference of each wheel for traction.
Slip the yarn through the hole in "Head.stl" down through the dome, tie a large not, secure it with glue, then pull the yarn back such that the knot is hidden within the dome.
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
After assembly of the wheels to the main axel, a small dot of thick cyanoacrylate is applied between "Wheel Section 1.stl" and "Axle Main.stl".
Comment if you have questions.

description.text: I had need for mallet so I whipped this up. It requires a 1.5 to 2 inch 1/4 inch screw and three nuts. Spin two of the nuts up to the head of the screw, insert the other in the handle, then bolt the head to the handle. The extra nuts give some weight to the head. You can make your own versions easily, I've included the freeCAD source (note that I said I whipped this up -- I haven't been super careful about organization, but most parts are named descriptively). This was printed on a Lulzbot Mini with 0.5mm nozzle -- if your nozzle is smaller, the fitment between head and handle might be loose -- you could scale the handle up a tiny bit to correct that. You'll also probably want to flip the heads over so the wide end is on the buildplate.

title: Dust Catch design for a Porter/Cable 680 and a standard 2.25"(5.715cm) Shop-Vac attachment

description.text: This is a dust catch I designed for my home CNC router. I use a Porter/Cable 680 router with a Rigid 5HP shop-vac. This is version 1 and I hope someone can find a use for it. I've added holes for set-screws to mount it to the router. I think it might be good to cut a length of rubber to go around the inner circumference of the router attachment as it will add better adhesion and act as a grommet. I've also added a hole on the shop vac attachment to put a set screw. My thoughts on that are that if the vaccum hose is to heavy and pulls off the catch from the router then I can make a simple piece to attach it to the router mount if need be. If this happens I will update the model with that piece. Thanks and enjoy.

title: Peon248 - longer frame for  Peon230 Quadcopter

description.text:
I wanted a bit longer frame for the otherwise great Peon230 quad frame by Tech2C.
As quick hack, I simply cut the STL mesh files (Peon230_Base_v1.1.stl and Peon230_Top_v1.1.stl) into 2 parts (with Meshimixer Linux) to overcome Tinkercad STL upload triangle limit. In Tinkercad I mirrored the 2 longer frame parts (back part of Peon230 frame) and joined them together in the middle. Then I used part of the front of Peon230 to make the front the same as original. The resulting frame gives you ~248mmm diagonal, thus Peon248 :) Motor shaft distance front-to-back becomes ~158mm and side-to-side reamins the original 190mm of course.
Came out nice printed in orange PLA 30% infill, 3 shells, 3 top and bottom layers.

author: ashortaznkid

title: Belted extruder gears for Greg's Wade / L3K and many more

description.text:
UPDATE (06-FEB-2017): After a year of flawless work with the ABS Crown pulley I had some aluminum pulleys around and ended using an aluminum standard GT2/60T pulley with a GT2/16T pulley. Added a model for a manual handler fixed to the pulley with M3 screws. Torque of 1:3.75. 580 Steps for 16 microstepping pololus and standard 8mm hobbed bolt. No so cheap but more durable/precise. Used high torque 160mm S2M belts. Don't know why, but extrusion seems to be smoother now. I'll update this when I have more info. Caution with your version/lenght of the hobbed bolt due to the 60T pulley's extra height. I have attached it to the bolt threads with m3 showt screws, and the handler with regular M3 screws. Used an M3 nut with anti slip to fix even more the pulley but that's not required. Printed the handler in black ABS as after a year working with the plastic pulley it's not any more as pretty white as in the original pics show here heheh, so I opted for a more discrete black handler, you know... UPDATE: (23-APR-2016): Posted sources as requested. Not a clean code anyway, sorry. UPDATE: (29-SEP-2015) Bunch of new models for cool style gears. Choose yours!!! Why enigma has an 'O'??? Why the "crown" model is so cool??? This is a GT2 gear I made with this excelent generator: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:994807. I made some modifications to the original design just to make it fit in a L3K extruder with GT2 pulleys and a 6mm 200mm 100T GT2 belt. As I was previously using typical wade's 47T/9T herringbone gears, this also fits on ANY extruder using that gears without changes. I know there are quite a few designs out there but I wanted some minor modifications to work with the materials I have around. I spent some time testing/adjusting/designing this till I got a consistent solution, so I wanted to share my results. Thanks to all other those awesome designs for inspiring me. This is tested and working, ready to print and install without modification. Two versions are available for 16T/90T pulley and 20T/86T pulley. You just need the belt and the pulley and you are done. I only put here the TESTED STL's, you can use the generator to make your own. Extruder backlash and retraction clicks eliminated. Bye bye wearing down of the gears. More durable and more torque. Silent operation and also very cool!!! Print it slowly, you want a fine teeth definition. Remember you have to recalculate the extruder steps on your firmware according to your setup. As always an extruder calibration is recommended after the setup. You will not regret. I should have done this a lot of time ago. Easy to install: I didn't even remove the extruder from the printer, not even the hobbed bolt, just changed gears loosening a bit the motor screws. Work done in less than five minutes. Add another five minutes to edit the Esteps and upload the firmware. With a little BOM of five bucks, regardless of the couple hours printing time and extruder motor recallibration time (recommended from time to time), doesn't it worth ten minutes? FYI: 90T/16T pulleys 5.625 torque factor (835 typical ESteps with 8mm bolt & 16x microstepping). 86T/20T pulleys 4.3 torque factor (638 typical ESteps with 8mm bolt & 16x microstepping). 90T/16T recommended for torque reasons, typical 47/9 gears torque factor is 5.222. Note these are theorical values, you have to calibrate your particular setup according to the hobbed bolt you are using. For example in a "real world" calibration for my 90T/16T setup I got >900 Esteps due to my special hobbed bolt having a 6.24mm effective diameter. Also remember you HAVE TO INVERT the extruder motor direction, belted gears works rotating both in the same direction, unlike typical geared ones; just invert the motor cable connection to your electronics. Install the belt TIGHT, don't use a DIY glued belt cause it will ruin the stability, durability and strengh of the build. Although you can print a small gt2 gear I recommend to use a aluminum one for the same reason, most of the mechanical stress is on the little gear and small plastic tooth are a bad idea for this if you want it to last long (One of the goals of the build). Don't use S2M belts, they are very similar to GT2 but with a different tooth profile, they could work but not tested and not recommended. Different belt gears than GT2 could be done, just ask if interested. Just in case you don't have it around: Formula to calculate the steps for your firmware:
ESteps = ((BigGearTeeth / SmallGearTeeth) x (MotorStepsPerTurn x Microstepping) ) / (PI x EffectiveHobbedBoltDiameter).
For example: with a 8mm hobbed bolt with a 6.86mm effective diameter, a 1.8º 200 step motor with 16x microstepping electronics and a set of 90T/16T gears we have:
ESteps=((90/16) x (200x16)) / (3.1415926535x6.86) = 835.2154 Steps theorical value.
Hint: Measure accurately your effective hobbed bolt diameter (use a digital caliper if you can) to obtain a realistic ESteps value. Put comments in your firmware sources with the measures and calculations, Don't behave like comments increase the size of the generated code... BOM:
GT2 Pulley 16T, 6.5mm length, 5mm Bore 2 bucks (Available at any 3Dprinter store)
GT2 belt closed loop, 100T, 200mm, 6mm tall 1 buck (Chinese Ebay 5x packs available for 5 bucks)
TOTAL of 3 bucks, oh!! come on!!! Happy belting !!!

comments.text: Hmmm. Got it!. I always file a bit all my builds. This is a tolerances related issue. As I usually do this, I forgot to mention it here. Maybe this could avoid I my builds to have this issue. A bit of sanding on the teeth could have been the solution to your problem but it seems you have printed it in PLA and thereof sanding on those little contours in this material would be unthinkable.
comments.author: captainserious

comments.text: I definitely printed in ABS. In between the modeling software, stl export, slicing, gcode generation and the physical 3D Printer, there are a lot of opportunities for variation. I don't think having to scale it a bit is a big problem, especially when you can nail it on print #2 by using some simple math. With a toothed pulley, the print has to be dang near perfect. This isn't some yoda head nicknack.
comments.author: magonegro

comments.text: Strange thing. I printed out almost ten pulleys and didnt have that problem. What pulley did you print? 90 teeth or 86 teeth? Were you tensioning enough the belts? I assume your printer is well calibrated, so I can't understand what happened to you. Anyway, thanks for sharing your experience.
comments.author: captainserious

comments.text: I did the 86 tooth pulley for use with the 20 tooth on the motor. The Afinia is pretty good at being dimensionally accurate.

title: Desk Lamp Clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The included files will print the three parts needed to replace the clamp for the standard office spring arm lamp. Note that I included two sets, one for a 5/16" hook bolt, and another for a 1/4" hook bolt. While the 1/4" should work for the newer light duty lamps, the 5/16" was a better fit for a salvaged heavy duty lamp I used. I could not find L bolts with machine threads, so I had to use a hook bolt and hammer it open so it came close to a L bolt. The nuts that came with it are fitted into the triangular knob. (updated 5/16" knob to have slightly thicker outer edge at the nut) If you find my designs useful, please help by donating.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium or Low is fine

Infill:

20% is good enough

Notes: Increase the shell to at least 2mm, since this is a structural part. It is designed to have increased strength through the pattern and holes; so there should be no need to have an infill of more than 20%. There is only one overhang spot and it doesn't need to be perfect and it came out great without support. I suggest use ABS filament due to its strength.

comments.text: Yeah, I made the 5/16 version. I'm wondering if the slight bend was due to me printing it solid? On the knob, some slight gaping occurred at the top of the print, near in the recesses. But it turns out the corners in the 3 (handles?) of the knob, paired with the thickness of the knobs' bottom, seem to make it adequately strong enough. As for what I used for the bolt: at Home Depot I found a 5/16 'U' bolt with nuts included for $1.25. I had the tool rental dept cut it in half for me, in-store. Then I put the bolt in a vice, and using a mini-sledge, hammered it into a 90 degree 'L' bolt. Works perfectly! Thank you for designing this!  What software did you use to create it?
comments.author: Hellpepper

comments.text: I designed it with 123D.  I am just switching over to using Fusion 360 for newer designs.
comments.author: Hellpepper

comments.text: I made this, and it turned out fairly well. The flat bottoms did round out a bit, I'm not sure how to prevent this. Also, the 3 corner points of the nut cavity on the knob that are thinnest will need to be reinforced on the model, as this is a significant weak spot.
comments.author: Hellpepper

title: Openbuilds v-slot z axis for Lulzbot Taz 4/5 Printers

description.text: This modification adds Openrail extrusions in place of the existing Lulzbot Taz 4 or 5 smooth Z rod. I will post a parts list soon. It basically just needs 8 of the mini wheels, with 4 mini wheel eccentrics and 4 6mm spacers. Extrusions are 20mm x 20mm openrail 500mm extrusions, stock. You will also need some T slot nuts (m5, I recommend the Dropin ones for this) 4 spacers and longer M5 bolts to move the control box out fromt he frame to clear the wheels, and several longer M3 bolts. THis project also has an option to replace the existing stock heat set insert based Z endstop with a full on Micrometer body, which I highly recommend. Edit: Uploaded a new version of the bearing carriage. This version has sufficient clearance to work with my new Anti wobble nut project. If you dio not intend to fit that project, the older version is fine. The anti wobble Z nut mount project may be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1089626 Edit 2: wobble clearance block with passthrough slot for the Z endstop cable now uploaded.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

printed with 0.50mm nozzle

Infill:

85%

Notes: You want a pretty dense infil for these as they will be structural. I would not recommend PLA for this application. The Z motor brackets and top plates are quite large and cannot be printed on a mini.
Tell us more...

Insrtructions It appears Thingiverse ate my origional instructions section. Will need to rebuild it later. For now here's the Bill of materials Z axis Bill of Materials 6 M5 heat set inserts http://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a361/=zhts4o
4 3/16" 1 and 3/4" long steel shafts (locally sourced from Ace Hardware)
8 Igus 2MTRI MYI-03-03 Flanged Bearing, 3/16" IDx 3/16" L (ebay)
8 1/4" threaded nylon spacers, at least 1/2" length
8 bolts that will fit the threaded nylon spacers Openbuilds Z axis:
8 Xtreme Mini V Wheel™ Kit http://openbuildspartstore.com/xtreme-mini-v-wheel-kit/
8 30mm Low profile head M5 bolts http://openbuildspartstore.com/low-profile-screws-m5/
2 20mm x 20mm x 500mm Openbuilds V slot extrusions http://openbuildspartstore.com/v-slot-linear-rail/
4 6mm eccentric spacer http://openbuildspartstore.com/eccentric-spacer/
4 6mm solid spacer http://openbuildspartstore.com/aluminum-spacers/
8 12mm long thread m3 cap head bolts
18 M5 10mm Cap head bolts (the support braces require 3 each, for double bracing, add 6 bolts and T-nuts)
22 additional M5 T-nuts (I reccommend the drop in ones for these, they make it considerably easier
12mm long Cap low profile cap head bolts (M5) for securing control box spaced out to clear boltheads
1 M5 heat set insert if you will not be doing the micrometer upgrade
12 M5 washers Stock parts that will be reused:
The Z height set bolt spring assembly
The existing M5 bolts, washers, and T-nuts that secure the stock Taz 5 Motor mounts, and upper leadscrew mounts to the chassis frame

comments.text: I believe this is "V-slot" extrusion, not "Openrail". Openrail is a rail system that you can bolt to metric extrusion. V-slot has the tapered grooves integrated into the extrusion channels. Makerslide has a rail edge in the extrusion, which is what my ORD Hadron uses.

Here is a small part that twists into the Makerslide rail and rests on the T-nut / set screw (for extra support) that most Ord Bots use for Z-Axis home control. It has a hole for a M5 machine screw that can be "micro-adjusted" for precise, and easy, Z-home setup. **THIS REALLY IS RUBBISH, GET MY VERSION 2.0: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:239696

You can use any screw you like, you only need to adjust the hole diameter in Blender or the STL editor ofyour choice.  After that:  
1) Print with any layer height (shouldn't matter) and middle of the road fill (I used 50%).  
2) Home the Z-Axis (to give yourself an idea of a starting point)  
3) Lower the height of the T-nut  
4) Tap the hole with a M5 screw and then twist part in to place above the T-Nut and roughly where home should be (at the top of the screw head)  
5) Slide the T-Nut up beneath the new part and tighten the set screw  
6) Adjust home to your liking by turning the screw in small increments
